Angela Merkel set for 4th term after Social Democrats OK coalition Jordans (2018) March 4, states that: BERLIN (AP) — Germany ended months of political uncertainty Sunday when Chancellor Angela Merkel gained the support needed to preserve her governing coalition and secure a fourth term as leader of Europe’s most powerful economy. The center-left Social Democrats voted overwhelmingly to remain in a coalition with Merkel’s conservative bloc, after difficult and drawn-out negotiations triggered by September’s elections, which saw the rise of a new right-wing force in German politics and raised questions about Merkel’s future. Parliament is expected to meet March 14 to re-elect Merkel as chancellor, ending the longest time Germany has been without a new government after elections in its postwar history (para. 1-3). Angela Merkel Is About to Find Out If She'll Get Her Fourth Term Jennen (2018) March 3, states that: Angela Merkel is about to discover if she can begin a fourth term as German chancellor or if she’s headed for another election. With stable government in Europe’s biggest economy at stake, Germany’s Social Democratic Party plans to reveal on Sunday whether its members have voted to extend their coalition with Merkel through 2021. It’s the culmination of more than five months of party deadlock that have given Germany its longest bout of political uncertainty since World War II. If the SPD ballot goes Merkel’s way, she could be sworn in by mid-March, returning to the European and global stage with full policy-making powers. A rejection would push Germany into untested waters, with Merkel expected to govern without a parliamentary majority and an early election likely in the fall (para. 1-3). Hard to Call
Polls in the past two weeks suggest growing SPD support for the coalition pact that party leaders negotiated with Merkel’s Christian Democrat-led bloc last month. A Feb. 26-27 Infratest Dimap survey showed 66 percent of self-declared Social Democrat backers in favor (para. 6). Jennen, B. (2018). Angela Merkel Is About to Find Out If She'll Get Her Fourth Term. Bloomberg. Political. Retrieved from

Angela Merkel offers critic Jens Spahn cabinet post Buck (2018) February 25, states that: Angela Merkel confirmed that she would bring Jens Spahn, one of her fiercest rivals, into the next cabinet in a move that could give the banner carrier of the conservative wing of the Christian Democratic Union a platform to fight for her succession.  The German chancellor unveiled her list of CDU ministers for the next government after a meeting of party leaders on Sunday. As with previous high-level appointments, Ms Merkel’s decision will be scrutinised above all for signs of who is best placed to take over as party leader and, potentially, as chancellor once she retires. Ms Merkel is hoping to see through a fourth term as chancellor that would extend her tenure at the top of Europe’s largest economy to 16 years. Her immediate fate, however, is in the hands of the 460,000 members of the Social Democratic party, who have until the end of the week to vote in an internal referendum. Senior German conservatives urge shift to right as Merkel picks cabinet Chambers (2018) February 24, states that: BERLIN (Reuters) - Several senior German conservatives called on Saturday for their party to shift to the right to win back voters, throwing down the gauntlet to Chancellor Angela Merkel before she announces her choice of cabinet ministers on Sunday. The Christian Democrats (CDU) vote at a party meeting on Monday on whether to back a coalition deal with the Social Democrats (SPD), which would hand Merkel a fourth term at the top of a grand coalition and keep them in office for another four years. SPD members also have to vote on the agreement. Although the CDU is widely expected to back the deal - and approve Merkel’s ally, Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, as CDU general secretary - there are rumblings among conservatives that the party needs fresh blood and a new political direction. “Sometimes the conservative element of the conservative bloc could be more prominent,” CDU premier of the state of Schleswig Holstein, Daniel Guenther, told the Neue Osnabruecker newspaper (para. 1-4). German Government Hinges on Party Tally Pancevski (2018) Feb. 22, states that: BERLIN—Germany’s political future is staked on a ballot among the fractious rank-and-file of a once-mighty party that is still reeling months after its worst electoral showing since World War II. Some 460,000 members of the ailing Social Democratic Party will decide by the end of next week whether to renew its unloved coalition with the conservative Christian Democratic Union of Chancellor Angela Merkel or go into opposition, a choice that would push Europe’s largest economy into uncharted political territory (para. 1-2). It has taken hold despite Germany’s economic prowess, which long insulated it from the surge of outsider movements that have disrupted the establishment across the West (para. 5). “What we are experiencing here is part of a wave of social upheaval rolling across the Western world: in the U.K., in the U.S., and now in Germany,” said Norbert Röttgen, a senior CDU lawmaker and former minister in Ms. Merkel’s government (para. 9). But Ms. Merkel is diminished too. She remains Germany’s most popular politician and several polls show support for her party, though historically weak, has strengthened somewhat since the election. But the big concessions she made in the coalition negotiations—including granting a weakened SPD the powerful finance, labor and foreign ministries as well as tens of billions of euros in extra welfare spending—caused resentment in her own camp (para. 19). “Ms. Merkel has sacrificed the interests of the CDU simply to remain in power,” said Alexander Mitsch, chairman of the CDU Values Union, a conservative pro-business group within the party. “She should give up the chancellorship and open the way for a renewal of the party” (para. 19-20). Pancevski, B. (2018). German Government Hinges on Party Tally. The Wall Street Journal. World. Europe. Retrieved from

i've been a little worried about the whole SPD voting by post thing. It seems like a process fraught with tampering opportunities from origin to destination given the 460K + voters have a lot of sway right now and link below shows one bona-fide registration issue: http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/02/20/dog-gets-vote-whether-merkel-can-form-new-german-government/
This - tampering, is on my decision-making list as a factor but at this point, but I hold it to be pretty much negligible as the increase in new SPD voters doesn't seem to be more than 25K - not enough to influence the voting direction of the existing members. These would be long(ish)-time voters whose registration would be already on voter rolls from previous elections (whatever errors there are, and likley there are always some, would either be embedded or weeded out. This wasn't, it seems much of a concern, during previous elections.) The number of new registrants, which might have a lot more errors regarding eligibility aren't enough to sway the vote direction.
They had a peak sign-up in January of 6,000 and the number of total SPD registrants sits at around 460K.  Other points:
- Membership is accessible to anyone in terms of price and paperwork, initially 10 euros and a form, a full membership runs more $250 per quarter, I think
- Some existing SPD are talking about a mininum length of membership for newbies before being given voting privileges but nothing in stone and I don't think it will fly (seems against general principals of social democracy)

With Germany's new government, there are fears that years of fiscal discipline could be brought to an end Amaro (2018) Feb 15, states that: Germany could break away from years of fiscal discipline and become less of an economic example, amid plans by its new government to increase spending, analysts told CNBC. The largest euro zone economy has accustomed the world to running budget surpluses — when income or receipts overcome expenditures — or even small deficits compared to the rest of the region. Data released in January showed that Germany's public sector hit a record surplus of 3.4 billion euros ($4.24 billion) in 2017, indicating that the government has room to step up spending. However, analysts are concerned that increasing spending, which the new government aims to do by 48 billion euros, could be detrimental in the eventuality of economic shocks. "As long as the German economy continues to grow at such strong rates and I expect this to continue for two to three years, I do not expect a deficit," Joerg Kraemer, chief economist at Commerzbank, said Wednesday. "However, if something happens, and growth slows down, then we are quickly back in deficit territory as a new government will spend all the extra tax revenues for consumption." The last time Germany ran up a deficit, defined as the amount by which expenses or costs exceed income or revenues, was in 2013 by 0.1 percent of gross domestic product. According to Commerzbank, the coalition deal between Chancellor Angela Merkel's Christian Democrats (CDU) and the Socialist Democrats (SDP) will prove "costly." With a more relaxed approach to spending, should an economic shock occur, which could include a market sell-off and changes in monetary policy, Germany could be in trouble, the bank said (para 1-6). Amaro, S. (2018). With Germany's new government, there are fears that years of fiscal discipline could be brought to an end. CNBC. Europe News. Retrieved from
https://www.cnbc.com/2018/02/15/germany-new-government-fiscal-discipline-could-be-ending.html

Opinion: As CDU spats, Merkel retains her nerves of steel Deutsche Welle (2018) February 12, states that: Germany's chancellor is reaching out to critics in her party — kind of. Angela Merkel intends to remain the top Christian Democrat, and chances are good that she will succeed, DW's Jens Thurau writes. On Sunday, after a week without precedence in German politics, Chancellor Angela Merkel made a stunning appearance on the public broadcaster ZDF. Merkel had just reached a coalition agreement with the Social Democrats (SPD) in which her Christian Democrats (CDU) had forfeited all of their key cabinet positions — all except the Chancellery, of course. The Foreign and Finance ministries will be led by SPD politicians, even though the CDU was the clear winner of the elections in September. This was a spectacular achievement for the SPD, but it did not prevent the party from publicly falling apart. CDU members are not satisfied either. The GroKoNo movement has registered 25,000 new party members but I think they need much more for movement to be successful SPD voters seem to have  two questions:
1) can Social Democrat philosophy exist and survive in a coalition? - likely 'No' because Martin Schulz' has very little support now and this would further wane as coalition ruled. Finance Minister post might be enough to placate - but it's not like that post can act without adhering to the imposed will of the Chancellor and majority party
2) Will AfD have more voice/power as opposition than SPD would as an adjuct to a dominant CDU? 'Yes' that is the nature of second dominant party when first and third align - third only has more power in this scenario as an independent. They are smaller weight than opposition but they have independence to switch sides, remain an island, generally muddy up the leading party plans if they want. As a coalition they have no pull and only one direction -- that of the number 1 party. Because these two questions can only be solved, from SPD's persepctive, by voting 'No" in referendum, and because voters tend to do the unthinkable when they think they have only one chance to do it (Brexit/trump/Barcelona/Supreme Court of Zimbabwe, etc.), and because  I think Kunhert has done a  good job of promoting this referendum as a 'Hail Mary, last chance' for the survival of the party. I read the discussion between @Nik, @shivadiva and @SMH5 below. @Nik as far as I understand the situation your statement isn't correct:
There is nothing that forces the Bundestag to vote on a new chancellor. For that the Bundespraesident must nominate someone [1], if then at least 50% of the members of Bundestag vote for this person he/she must be named chancellor by the president (that happens automatically, but is formally a separate step).
Now more interesting is when there is no absolute majority (50+% of all possible votes for one person), then there has to be a second vote within ?14 days? (unlike for the first vote that only depended on the President nominating someone). This vote is equivalent to the first one (i.e. absolute majority and automatic naming to chancellor). If that also fails there has to be a third one (I'm unsure about the timing here, but it is rather quickly), which is different:
In the third vote (actually a write-in vote) anyone with the most votes is nominated (i.e. only plurality is needed anymore), BUT the president has the choice of naming him/her chancellor OR calling for new elections. This is the only way to get to new elections without naming a chancellor first! The other way of triggering new elections would go like: Elect a chancellor (who must be proposed by the president for the first two votes), have that chancellor ask the "Vertrauensfrage" ("Do you trust me?"-question) and loose that on purpose. Now the president CAN call for new elections. [2] So unless Steinmeier plays ball there won't be new elections at all (until September 2021). He needs to desolve the Bundestag and order new elections, nobody can force him to do anything (except that he needs/wants to get reelected in a couple of years, there is no way of pressuring him) and he already said: I don't want new elections, deal with the situation (I.e. grow up). Now for this question it is relevant whether Merkel would count as elected when 
1) She gets a majority in votes 1 or 2, but immediately looses a Vertrauensfrage. I'd say yes, she had to be chancellor to ask that question.
2a) She is elected in the 3rd vote, and Steinmeier does name her (likely). I'd say yes.
2b) She is elected in the 3rd vote, but Steinmeier doesn't name her (unlikely) and calls for new elections. I'd say no
3) Someone else is elected in the 3rd vote (rather unlikely). I'd say no independently of Steinmeier's choice
4) Someone else is elected in the 1st or 2nd vote (highly unlikely). I'd say no There is, imo, no absolut majority without the CDU (Merkel's party). This would require cooperation between FDP or AFD and Lefts or Greens, which is next to impossible except on smallish issues. None of these cooperations would be something anyone wants to form a government on.
If the CDU needs to be part of the government, they'll also want to lead it, which makes the other way of not getting Merkel a revolt in her party. The chances here aren't actually that bad, but since the likely candidate (Jens Spahn) is significantly to Merkel's right (making forming a coalition w/o AFD impossible) there is no way for him to be chancellor of a stable government (i.e. getting elected in votes 1 or 2). If the situation stretches out for a few additional month I can see him (or someone like him) taking the chances, i.e. getting elected in vote 3, hoping that Steinmeier names him and leading a minority government. But that is an awful risky move for someone that young (and with Merkel necessarily retiring in the next 4 years). So the real question becomes: Is Merkel or Steinmeier first getting annoyed and retiring. Which is about the only way I see Merkel not being elected, not that it wouldn't have been far better if Merkel had decided to retire in the first place. [1] I'm actually unsure whether the nominated person can say: No I don't want to be nominated, or if he/she can only say: I don't accept the proclamation
[2] If he doesn't call for new elections the situation is exactly the same as of now: We would have an acting government (now under the new chancellor) and the president would need to nominate someone for the 1st vote. Trivia: I'm not sure if this question, technically, should be able to resolve in a yes at all, as the act of becoming chancellor is by being named by the president and NOT by the vote in the Bundestag.

Angela Merkel’s Future Hinges on German SPD’s Vote on Forming Coalition Thomas (2018) Jan. 18, states that: BERLIN—The fate of Europe’s longest-serving leader still in office will be sealed Sunday by a fractious political party that has lost half of its voters and used up six leaders in the past 15 years. Four months after Germany’s center-left Social Democratic Party scored their worst postwar result in a general election, 600 of the party’s delegates will meet to decide whether to forge a ruling alliance with Angela Merkel’s conservatives and usher in the German chancellor’s fourth term in office. A “yes” vote would kick-start detailed coalition negotiations between the two partners. A “no” vote would almost certainly lead to snap elections, tip Europe’s largest economy into renewed political uncertainty, and could even spell the end of Ms. Merkel’s remarkably long political career. Sunday’s vote is an extreme example of how the weakening of the moderate left across Europe is scrambling the Continent’s politics. Without any other party in parliament with which to forge an alliance, Ms. Merkel would be left with a difficult choice between forming an unstable minority government or seeking fresh elections. So split is the SPD that few observers are daring to make a prediction about the outcome of the vote. The entire leadership behind chairman Martin Schulz is calling for a “yes.” Left-leaning midlevel functionaries, the party’s youth organizations, some regional grandees and local chapters want to reject the alliance (para. 1-5). A “yes” vote on Sunday wouldn’t be the last hurdle to the formation of a government. Mr. Schulz, the SPD chairman, has pledged to put the detailed coalition agreement yet to be hammered out to the party’s 440,000 members. (para 19). But with these members being far more open to a coalition—61% favor it according to Thursday’s Forsa poll—than the 600 functionaries who will be voting Sunday, observers see this final test as a far easier one to pass. A “no” vote, by contrast, wouldn’t only bury the coalition talks but also likely seal the fate of Mr. Schulz as SPD chairman and that of his closest allies at the top—a prospect that opponents of a coalition said was an acceptable risk to take to save the party’s soul (para. 19-21). Thomas, A. (2018). Angela Merkel’s Future Hinges on German SPD’s Vote on Forming Coalition. The Wall Street Journal. World. Europe. Retrieved from

Split Social Democrats could sink Merkel's coalition plans Chambers and Käckenhoff (2018) Jan 16, states that: BERLIN/DUESSELDORF (Reuters) - The leader of Germany’s Social Democrats (SPD) tried on Tuesday to quash a grassroots rebellion against a blueprint agreed with Angela Merkel’s conservatives to enter formal talks on a “grand coalition” which could scupper her plan for a fourth term. After five days of talks, SPD leader Martin Schulz agreed a framework deal with Merkel and Bavarian conservatives on Friday. But before he can start official negotiations he needs the backing of his party in a vote at a conference on Sunday. Convincing them is proving difficult. Two regional branches have already said they do not back his deal. Many rank and file members accuse Schulz of selling out to Merkel and failing to win a signature policy to take to coalition talks, such as a major healthcare reform or tax hikes for the rich (para. 1-3). However, it is difficult to predict the outcome of Sunday’s vote as the regional results are not binding. At the Bonn congress 600 delegates are free to vote how they wish (para. 18). Some conservatives have expressed confidence that the SPD will back the blueprint. “I can only recommend moving at top speed,” said Bavarian conservative Alexander Dobrindt (para 22.). “I look forward to starting coalition negotiations on Monday,” he said, adding his only concern was the “masochistic way” the SPD had of talking down its successes (para. 22-23). Merkel Reaches 'Grand Coalition' Breakthrough with Social Democrats (FT)
Angela Merkel's conservative bloc and its left-of-center rivals the Social Democrats have achieved a breakthrough in exploratory talks on forming a new "grand coalition", raising hopes of an end to the political deadlock that has gripped Germany since inconclusive elections in September. The breakthrough came during talks this morning between Merkel, Horst Seehofer, leader of the Bavarian CSU, and Martin Schulz, the Social Democrat chief. The three will now recommend to their parties that they start official coalition talks. The euro rallied after the terms of the coalition deal emerged, reaching its highest level against the dollar since January 2015. The SPD will first have to give the green light for formal coalition talks, and any coalition agreement will also have to be voted on by its members. Yet today's breakthrough is still the first concrete sign that Germany's long-running political crisis may finally be coming to an end.

I originally wasn't going to bother with this question, but I saw this article recently (http://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/blog/the-german-tank-problem.html) on Hacker News, and it got me thinking... Assuming that most of the new phones sold would be the new ones, i.e. iPhone 6S and iPhone 6S Pluses, I used serial numbers off eBay in the UK (from product photos) to work out how many phones there were approximately in the country. I then found the worldwide number of 6Ss, using the market share of Apple in the UK relative to the world and the smartphone market size of the UK, relative to the world. Then, I used the released sales figures for Q4 2015 to account for those that were sold in that quarter. Finally, I used a linear projection to work out, based upon the number of phones sold so far in this quarter, the total for Q1 2016, which I project to be 82.4 million phones. This of course ignores Christmas, which I might have to revisit in the future. Another, less interesting way (in my opinion i.e. no less valid), is to look at what happens to sales in the quarter after Apple releases a new phone internationally (i.e. from the iPhone 3GS onwards). In more recent years this has always neatly been at the end of the 4th quarter (i.e. the one before December), but in previous years this has been more towards the beginning of a quarter. Looking at the geometric mean of the factor difference between the quarter where most of the new sales occurs and previous one, there is projected to be 82.9 million phones sold in Q1 2016. Both methods are pretty conclusively above 75 million, although the standard deviation on the Bayesian method is considerable - I need to crunch the stats properly to quantify it, but it looks to be roughly a 10% chance it'll be below 75M. Why your opinion polls and journalists don't add anything substantial to your forecast:  1. Angela Merkel does not need 355 members, or 50% plus one.  She only requires the loyalty of 239 in the Bundestag to form a government. That is 33.7% of the Bundestag. Much less than 50% will form a “majority” government. 2. How powerful are 239 Germans? The majority government would only represent 25% of the German population; and the power and leanings of these 25% would govern the remainder of Berlin, the other 15 states, much of Brussels as well as the rest of Western Europe—including London, Northern Ireland and the rest of Great Britain, because they remain in the EEC (European Economic Community). Moreover, Japanese companies and others have to pick a legislative regime, either California's (@lsgold7) or Brussels'. 3. Here is how it works, in simple terms:  For any German party, Angela Merkel and Martin Schulz only need half of their own members. They form a dominant bloc that holds the cards to control the other half of their party.  For a comfortable dominance in conservative parties, Angela Merkel might want to have two-thirds on her payroll, who in turn control offices and budgets of the remaining third. The dependency keeps them either weak, or loyal. 4. In numbers, party (share within the parliamentary group): — CDU 132 members (66%) 
— CSU 30 members (66%)
— SPD 77 members (50% + 1)
======
Minimal coalition: 239 members (approx. 33.7% of the Bundestag) 5. Number of the remainder, who needs to be controlled: 116.  116 + 239 = 355
709 seats × 50% = 354.5 6. Bolstered by controlling the other (un-) constitutional organs, the presidency, courts and central bank(s); the absolute power of a minority is assured. 7. The opposition of 354 seats don't matter at all; while 116 inside the government coalition might disagree, they will receive enough attention to be kept in control. 8. While roughly two-third of the Bundestag might object Angela Merkel as chancellor, she only have to take care of 116 of them. 9. “Jamaika” would have required 236, as a minimal coalition, or three less. Political Science concept applied: “minimal coalition” (William Riker)

@Anneinak

There is no deadline up to which the Bundestag has to elect a chancellor. It could quite possibly be that we won't have a new chancellor until the 2021 Bundestag election. In order to trigger a new election the Bundespraesident would have to dissolve the Bundestag. He MAY do that after the election of a chancellor failed twice (by not getting an absolute majority) AND he decides not to nominate the winner (by plurality) of the third vote in the Bundestag AND he does not decide to tell Bundestag to get its act together and elect a chancellor by majority. Currently there is no indication that Steinmeier (the president) has any intention of calling for new elections, which leaves 4 ways to resolve this question: 
1) A coalition forms (most likely SPD+CDU now) electing Merkel with absolute majority, 
2) the CDU declares that they want to form a minority  government under Merkel and gets elected (probably with some of the votes from all parties with the possible exception of AfD and Left). 
3) Someone does point 2), this could either be the CDU with a different person or a different party with a different coalition
4) There is no election where anyone gets a majority and the old government stays in an acting capacity until the next Bundestag is elected in 2021 There is no indication for 3) and it is hard to imagine getting a coalition from the other parties even to elect a chancellor. The likely scenarios are 1) or 2) with 1) being the slight favourite, although the SPD is rather unpredictable (mostly due to their leadership being divided and unclear). 4) would put an increasing amount of pressure on Steinmeier to dissolve the Bundestag, but there is NO way of forcing him to do anything and he is the only person that can dissolve the Bundestag. So this question largely reduces to: Will Steinmeier dissolve the Bundestag or will some coalition be formed to elect Merkel?

One interesting wrinkle in the semantics of the question: as pointed by @Khalid, the road to new elections passes through 3 votes in the Bundestag, the last one of which is just by relative majority. Yet the German President is not bound by this third vote - he can still dissolve the parliament even if the Chancellor is approved. So if the political parties agree to  go this route, it is possible that Merkel is technically elected as a Chancellor yet there are new elections. The GJO should clarify how would they score the question in this case as well. My 20% for a "no" are mostly for the case where Merkel does not receive even a relative majority - i.e., even in the third vote a majority of Bundestag MPs vote against her. Hard to judge how likely is that - on the one hand, in an arranged solution most opposing MPs may simply abstain; on the other hand, they may want to make sure that a minority government is firmly off the table. There is also a small possibility that Merkel may voluntarily withdraw, if this is the price for forming a coalition with the SDP, but for the moment this appears unlikely.

We could be getting into semantics with this question. If a new election takes place it will (almost certainly) be in 2018. 2018 is "after the 2017 Bundestage election", so in one reading of the meaning of the question if Mrs Merkel gets elected chancellor anytime in the future the answer to the question will be "yes". But an alternative meaning of "after the 2917 election" could be "as a consequence or result of the 2017 election" which an election in 2018 would not be.  Commentators have been making contradictory statements; that another election would probably produce the same result; and that Germans do not like uncertainty.  If they don't like uncertainty voters who voted for Die Linke, Grune, FDP or could vote for some other party, because the only certainty that voting for any of these parties is, is that they will not win, but who would govern Germany would be unknown.  My guess is that having made a protest some of the AfD could switch to the CDU/CSU (and some of the FDP voters could switch to the CDU/CSU and some Grune could switch to the SPD.) On the other hand the Grune and FDP could worry that they will lose support if another election is held and try harder to form a coalition. 
One thing is certain the UKs hope that Mrs Merkel's difficulties can be exploited to the UK's advantage are just another case of wishful thinking.

"Green concessions raise hopes of German coalition breakthrough - Climate and energy prove sticking points in progress to form a new government
YESTERDAY Guy Chazan in Berlin 
Germany’s Greens say they will compromise on some of their big demands such as an end date for petrol and diesel cars in an important concession that could break the logjam in talks to form a new coalition government. The talks follow September’s inconclusive elections when the two main parties — Angela Merkel’s conservative CDU/CSU bloc and the Social Democrats — slumped to their worst result since 1949. Ever since, Ms Merkel has been trying to cobble together an unwieldy coalition with the Greens and the liberal FDP, two parties with vastly divergent views on everything from climate policy to tax reform and the future of Europe. Progress in the exploratory talks has been so slow that some in the FDP have even suggested Germany might have to hold new elections — a prospect most parties view with horror. The big sticking points are immigration, climate and energy, with the Greens insisting that the coalition partners commit to banning the sale of petrol and diesel cars by 2030, and shutting down Germany’s 20 most polluting coal-fired power stations. The FDP and CSU, the Bavarian sister party of Ms Merkel’s CDU, both reject any attempt to impose a hard-and-fast date for banning sales of the combustion engine. But in an interview with the Stuttgarter Zeitung on Tuesday, Green co-chair Cem Ozdemir said the party could compromise on a cut-off date for cars if there was a “clear commitment that we will do everything possible to have the vehicles of the future — interconnected, automated and emissions-free”. This could include stronger incentives for electric vehicles as well as driver bans in inner-city areas for older, more polluting diesel cars. Other Green leaders also showed flexibility on coal. “For us it’s not a question of whether the last coal-fired power station is taken offline in 2030 or 2032 — we’re pragmatic on that,” party chairman Simone Peter told the Rheinische Post. “For us it’s more important that CO2 emissions in 2020 are 40 per cent lower than they were in 1990 and that the sectoral targets for 2030 are adhered to.” The four parties hope they will reach an agreement by mid-November that will form the basis for formal coalition negotiations. That preliminary deal will have to be approved by the Greens at their party conference on November 25. If it is rejected, the prospects for “Jamaica” — so-called because the partners’ party colours match those of the Jamaican flag — will fade. It is unclear at this stage whether the Greens’ willingness to compromise will have any discernible effect on the progress of talks. The FDP is still strongly opposed to driver bans for diesel cars and to aggressive action against Germany’s coal industry. “We weren’t elected to abolish hundreds and thousands of jobs,” said Wolfgang Kubicki, the FDP’s deputy leader. However, FDP leader Christian Lindner has also insisted that the FDP was “by no means a coal party”. It simply wanted to know from the Greens how Germany could have a stable energy supply without having to rely on “dirty electricity from Polish lignite” or from French nuclear power stations, he said."

EXCERPTED FROM THE ECONOMIST THIS AM: (OCT 18) Four into one? German coalition talks
Angela Merkel is no stranger to tough negotiations. That is just as well. Today she goes into what may be her toughest yet: talks to create a four-way “Jamaica” government of her Christian Democrats, the Christian Social Union (their Bavarian sister party), the pro-business Free Democrats and the Greens. Apart from another grand coalition with the Social Democrats, which the centre-left party has ruled out, this looks like the only arithmetically viable government following Germany’s election in September. Creating it will not be easy. The Christian Democrats are weakened by their poor result in the poll. The Christian Social Union did even worse, so is in revolt against Mrs Merkel. The Free Democrats have drawn a series of red lines, including an insistence on running the finance ministry. The Greens, meanwhile, must square any deal with their left-wing base. An agreement between the four sides is probable, but may take until January.
Looks like it'll be a slog to duct-tape together a coalition, but there are no other plausible contenders.

(1) First polls after TV debate don't show any shift in the polls. This is no good news for Martin Schulz. (2) For Merkel not to become chancellor, we basically need that CDU-FDP do not get a majority AND that SPD-FDP-Greens or SPD-Green-Left get a majority. Even then, CDU-Greens or CDU-FDP-Greens (the so-called 'Jamaica' option) could be alternatives. At the moment, both SPD-FDP-Green and SPD-Green-Left  fall about 10% short of a majority, which is pretty huge 2 weeks before the election.  (3) A 538-like model for the German election puts the probability of Merkel staying chancellor at 99.9%: https://www.inwt-statistics.de/blog-artikel-lesen/wahlprognose-fuer-die-bundestagswahl-2017.html#Prognose (link in German) However, this seems too confident given that we do not have that much data about Bundestag elections with so many different parties likely to get a seat, so that we don't know enough about the expected polling error in a (probably) 6-party parliament.  I would also put the chance of Merkel becoming incapable of holding office before the chancellor election (which will probably be in late November / early December) at higher than 1 in a thousand. Finally, looking at western European countries which traditionally have more parties in parliament, like the Netherlands, Belgium and Italy, we also should not rule out that all coalition talks fail and a reelection is called (there is also precedent for this on the state-level in Germany).

In German Election Campaign, Third Place Is the Real Winner Troianovski (2017) Aug 13, states that: Germany’s general election campaign kicked off in earnest over the weekend and it promises to be a nail-biter—for third place. Chancellor Angela Merkel looks like a sure bet to win a fourth term as the head of Europe’s biggest economic power when the country votes in late September. Her center-right alliance has a 15-point polling lead over its closest challenger, the center-left Social Democratic Party, or SPD, of candidate Martin Schulz. Ms. Merkel’s campaign slogan—“For a Germany in which we live well and happily”—channels a public mood wary of change. In a 40-minute speech to supporters in the city of Dortmund on Saturday that opened six weeks of campaigning, she didn’t even mention her opponent by name. But behind the confident Ms. Merkel and the struggling Mr. Schulz are four smaller parties in a mad dash for the bronze—a race likely to determine the makeup of the next government and Germany’s political direction for the next four years. Ms. Merkel is almost certain to need a coalition partner to govern. Only once since World War II has a single party won an outright majority. Ms. Merkel’s current government is a “grand coalition” bringing together Germany’s two main political blocs—her conservatives and Mr. Schulz’s Social Democrats. His party disdains governing in Ms. Merkel’s shadow, and conservatives also say that such a broad coalition should be the exception rather than the rule in German democracy (para. 1-5). Merkel tells voters: Brexit, French poll changed my view on Europe Nienaber (2017) July 15, states that: ZINGST, Germany (Reuters) - German Chancellor Angela Merkel told voters on Saturday that Britain's decision to leave the European Union and France's election of President Emmanuel Macron had changed her view on the bloc, adding it was worth fighting for a stronger Europe. Merkel's comments, made in a speech in the Baltic Sea resort town of Zingst two months before a federal election, underline her personal determination to deepen European integration if she is re-elected for a fourth term. Calling European Union membership one of Germany's biggest strengths, Merkel said last year's Brexit decision and elections in France and the Netherlands, in which pro-European parties defeated populist candidates, had changed her perspective. "For many people, including myself, something changed when we saw the Britons want to leave, when we were worried about the outcome of the elections in France and the Netherlands," Merkel told voters, some of whom wore straw hats with black-red-and-gold hatbands, the colors of the German flag. The center-right chancellor admitted that the EU was far from perfect and that Brussels sometimes was too bureaucratic. "But we have realized in the past few months that Europe is more than just bureaucracy and economic regulation, that Europe and living together in the European Union have something to do with war and peace, that the decades of peace after World War Two would have been completely unthinkable without the European Union," Merkel said to applause. Many people in the past had taken the EU and its advantages for granted -- such as freedom of speech, freedom of religion and freedom to travel, said Merkel who grew up in communist East Germany (para.1-7). Nienaber, M. (2017). Merkel tells voters: Brexit, French poll changed my view on Europe. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from

I am not going for certainty (100%) because there is quite long time before the election and the UK result has shown that it is possible for a "strong and stable" leader to loose a lot of support in a badly run campaign. I agree that the populist right's support has declined in Europe and I agree that being close to Trump is not a vote winner in Europe, but its a stretch to conclude that the latter has caused the former. Evidence; Trump already existed before the UK EU referendum vote and it was known that Farage of UKIP had connections with the same people who were helping Trump. While Trump had not become US President, the US Presidential campaign was well known to people in Europe who had an interest in populism. The fact that Obama gave his view that leaving the EU was a bad idea did not help the Remain side, having Trump supporting the Leave side probably did nothing to help it, but neither did it stop Leave winning. The same applied to the Austrian elections, Trump existed at the time of both elections. True by the December election Trump had won the Presidential election, and I expect many Austrians were not Trump fans, but Trump had not yet become President so Austrians had no more knowledge of what effect he would have in December than they did in May.  
I think it more likely that European voters have seen that when Populist movements have won elections they have not been able to deliver on the instant improvement they said would follow.  European voters do to some extent notice what happens in elections in other European countries (they are all part of the EU, so it matters), but regard what happens is the US as a side show. Abortion, lack of gun control, lack of universal health care seem to almost all Europeans really strange issues to be arguing about. 
UKIP started losing support immediately after the referendum as its supporters started switching to the party that was delivering Brexit, Trump had nothing to do with it (he had not yet been elected, so why would being friends with Trump help UKIP with the Brexit vote, but support start to drop while UKIP was still friends with Trump a few months later?) UKIP changed its leader, support slumped more, UKIP changed its leader again support slumped more, the new leader was caught out on some untruths and lost a by-election , the one MP UKIP had resigned from UKIP, UKIP slumped some more.
When Mrs May called the UK General Election she was a long way ahead in the polls (in spite of holding hands with Trump). If the election had taken place two months earlier with no campaign May would have won by a landslide. I don't think Trump did anything in the 6 weeks of the campaign to make British voters decide they did not like him (they had already tried to get him banned from the country). Mrs May managed the lose the UK election without any help from the Trump effect. People did not like her and did not like her policies. No one in the UK cared if she was friends with Trump or not. In fact she was a lot closer to Trump in January (when she was polling very well) that she was in June.  Brexit has turned out to not nearly as simple as advertised, instant gratification did not follow the referendum. The whole of Europe can see what a mess the UK economy is in, it can see how badly it is going.  I think the Brexit effect has had a lot more to do with putting Europeans off populists.

The base rate for incumbency success of chancellors seeking re-election in Germany is 0,82 for 1949 to present and 0,71 for the period 1990 to present.
To date, the best way to have an eye on the public opinion seems to be poll aggregating making probabilistic judgments on who would win. Two such instruments are available:
-	https://www.inwt-statistics.de/blog-artikel-lesen/wahlprognose-fuer-die-bundestagswahl-2017.html#Prognose (German)
-	http://www.thecrosstab.com/germany-2017/ (English)
-	Raw data is provided here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_German_federal_election,_2017
The German page by INWT Statistics is also modeling the probability that Merkel can stay German Chancellor: to date this is 84,5 per cent. However there are some arguments this could be too high and some that this could be too low.
84,5 per cent is too low:
-	The poll aggregators model a red-red-green coalition (SPD-LEFT-Greens) as more likely than a Grand Coalition of CDU und SPD, if both were possible. This is a strong assumption since – first – voters do not prefer the red-red-green coalition and both, SPD and the LEFT, have a very considerable disagreement among leaders and rank-and-file to go ahead with such a coalition. If possible, I would say that the chances are – at best – 50 percent for this coalition to be formed. Schultz clearly signals to voters that he does not want form a coalition with the LEFT in the first place.
-	Given the fact that the SPD has to make a statement on coalition options and given the clear impression from several regional elections that red-red-green coalition is not preferred by the voters, it seems likely that this route to the Chancellorship is completely down for Martin Schulz, the candidate for Chancellorship of the SPD. The only route that he then has is a coalition with the Liberals and the Greens. But: If this kind of a ‘traffic light coalition’ would be possible and given that the CDU would have the biggest seat share (very, very likely: 99 percent) a CDU-Liberal-Green coalition would be possible, either. The Liberals and the Greens would be in the position to decide which side they would join and which of the candidates would become German Chancellor. Greens tend to the SPD camp, Liberals tend to the CDU camp. That would very likely end up in a stalemate. Consequence: Grand Coalition, Chancellor: Merkel.
-	Given the enormous success of the Liberals in the regional elections in North Rhine Westphalia (12+ percent), it could become more likely than pollsters currently measure that a CDU-Liberal government could be formed (if so, with a very tiny majority). So it seems that Merkel will have another realistic option to stay Chancellor – beside the Grand Coalition.
-	Merkel is probably least prone to political scandals among the Western leaders and candidates. A Fillon-like scandal in Germany seems very unlikely, but Merkel not even had to witness a scandal like some of her Cabinet members that – nevertheless – would not lead to their resignation. And this holds true if one looks back all the years she is in German politics. That makes her approval ratings and her electoral performance a reliable factor to count on.
-	Schulz and the SPD lack the magic triangle: a harmonizing combination of (1) Candidate, (2) an issue that voters have an interest in and (3) a favorable media agenda.
However, 84,5 per cent could be too high:
-	There is so much time until elections take place… Many things can happen. Merkel almost lost safe elections in 2005 against the – incumbent – Gerhard Schröder. Scandals among rank-and-file are always possible, particularly in the CDU – even if they seem to be harmless in international perspective.
-	It is very likely that the current offspring of the CDU and Liberal polls will normalize a bit an SPD will gain momentum. Too, it is likely that Schulz will find an issue and – may be, may be – media agenda will support him (most journalist in Germany lean toward the left side of the political spectrum).
-	It would be very awkward for Merkel and the CDU if there would be a terrorist attack with an Islamic background or something similar: a series of violent crimes with nationwide media coverage committed by refugees or other foreigners (because people blame Merkel personally for the refugee inflow in 2015; and national security and law-and-order is a unique selling point of the CDU). If refugee crisis would rebound it would be disastrous for the CDU. However, it is kind of the absurd situation in Germany in the Merkel era that such events would not be to the advantage of the SPD; rather, the Alternative for Germany (AfD) would profit from such events. – Even under these very unfavorable circumstances for the CDU: the Chancellor is very likely to stay Merkel!
All in all, it seems to date, that Merkel is fairly well ‘priced’ with 88 to 90 percent probability to stay Chancellor of Germany after the next parliamentary elections.

Angela Merkel’s Party Scores Big Win in Key German State Election Smale (2017) May 14, states that: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — The party of Chancellor Angela Merkel scored an upset victory on Sunday in elections in Germany’s most populous state that were seen as a dress rehearsal for national parliamentary elections in September, when she will seek a fourth term. The victory in North Rhine-Westphalia, home to 18 million people and one in five German voters, dealt a severe blow to Martin Schulz, Ms. Merkel’s Social Democratic challenger, who admitted to a bitter defeat in his home state, traditionally the leftists’ heartland. Cheers erupted at the state headquarters of Ms. Merkel’s Christian Democratic Union when early results came in. With almost all ballots counted, the Christian Democrats had won almost 33 percent of votes cast, compared with around 31 percent for the center-left Social Democrats. The national elections are still more than four months away — a long time in an era of febrile politics across Europe, where mainstream parties have seen their grip weaken in recent elections. But Ms. Merkel, in power since 2005, seems to be bucking the trend, buoyed by experience, a calm temperament and the exceptional economic strength of Germany, which has 4.1 percent unemployment and just last week announced record exports and tax revenues that will exceed expectations by 55 billion euros by 2020.
Mr. Schulz, reacting to the results, said that it was a “tough day” but that he and his party would now focus on winning the national elections in September. A deputy leader of the Social Democrats, Ralf Stegner, conceded minutes after exit polls suggested his party was headed for what he called a “bitter defeat.” The state leader of the party immediately resigned, in a clear effort to deflect blame for the defeat away from Mr. Schulz. Mr. Schulz rode a wave of hype and hope to sudden popularity early this year but has fizzled badly since. By contrast, Ms. Merkel has played up her status as a world leader and savored two unexpected clear victories for her party in other state elections, last week and in late March (para. 1-8). It should be remembered that it is NOT the German federal election that will decide whether Merkel will be elected chancellor. To all those who complain about how strange the American electoral system is: You haven't seen the Germans yet. It is the Bundestag, not the people, who decide who Germany's most powerful member of state is. The Bundestag is elected by the people, but they can vote for whomever they please. Usually, they vote according to party affiliation. Now, people might think that it's really a close race between CDU and SPD. However, that's where you would be mistaken, since the members of the Bundestag are decided by districts, (similar to the US's states electing the president). And, just like in America, you can have more Bundestags-people even without having the popular vote. Barring a major event, Merkel winning is all but certain. Edit for clarification: Found here a website (in german) that details the predicted number of seats in the Bundestag (sort of equivalent of the electoral college). https://bundestagswahl-2017.com/prognose/ Scroll down to the "Prognose für die Sitzverteilung im Bundestag", that chart shows which party will get how many votes. The gap that the SPD (red) needs to close is not insubstantial. Black (Merkel's party) will quite certainly have the most members, so they will be able to vote for Merkel once again.

In yesterday's Saarland state-election, the CDU won (40%) by a 3-5pp margin over the latest polls. This was due to a 10pp higher turnout (70%), where previous non-voters split disproportionally for the CDU. It is generally accepted (even the SPD candidate did not object in interviews), that this is due to voters taking a stand against a potential red-red(-green) coalition. [Side note: red-red-green describes a coalition of the centre-left SPD, the left Die Linke and green B’90/ Grüne.] The so-called ‘Schulzeffekt’ describing the boost in polls after Martin Schulz’s election to chair of the SPD did not materialise. The SPD took home 30% of the votes, which marks no change compared to the last election, though SPD politicians kept reiterating that they were up from 25% in the polls in January. It is also notable, that neither B’90/ Grüne nor the liberal FDP made the 5% barrier to be represented in parliament. The FDP is historically weak in Saarland, but regarding B’90/ Grüne, the CDU’s tactic of painting them as being predisposed towards a red-red-green coalition seems to be bear fruit. The AfD had also a below-average showing with 6% of the vote. In my opinion this is due to a couple of factors:
1.	People were clearly happy with the work of the last government, with 85% describing their economic situation as good. Saarland has also handled the 2015 refugee influx particularly well.
2.	The populist vote in Saarland skews towards Die Linke, which is prominent there due to former Saarland minister-president and former co-chair of the Linke, Oscar Lafontaine.
3.	As all major political parties have ruled out a coalition with AfD, they are reduced to a pure protest party, which will not be part of a government. In Saarland, the government will most likely remain a great coalition (Große Koalition) of (a slightly strengthened) CDU and SPD. I would be careful in reading too much into this election with regards to the federal election. While it is a good signal for the CDU, the Saarland with its population of 1m is not necessarily representative. The biggest shifts in the federal election can be expected to be in former GDR states (away from the centre towards the edges of the political spectrum) and in big cities (which favour the SPD).

COMMENT:  Schulz now leads the largest party in Germany, so theoretically, his party would win the election, and he, as its leader, would be empowered to create a government. Merkel, on the other hand, has been in office for many years, and the longer a person is in office, and the more decisions they've made, the more people that they may have alienated.  Bottomline:  Merkel is in trouble!

Well, there is a lot to consider here. There are two "mechanisms" of German politics that are essential for being elected as a Chancellor. First there is the election of course. The party with the most votes obtains the right to ... to select the Chancellor? Not directly. It's the right to form a coalition in order to get the majority in the German Bundestag and then to elect the Chancellor. As a consequence it gets a bit complicated here. Angela Merkel not only need to get the most votes but also a coalition partner to stay in power. Therefore she might be in a difficult situation after the election but her main competitor Martin Schulz is likely to be, too. There are different scenarios possible. If the Christian Democrats win the most votes they have -according to the polls right now- either the option to form a coalition with the Social Democrats or with Liberals and Greens together (current polls indicate Christian Democrats and Greens won't get enough seats in the German Bundestag to be in the majority). There are several obstacles building these coalitions. The Social Democrats are tired of being the junior partner of the Christian Democrats and are likely to refuse a coalition bid (although that is of course not determined). While there would have been less problems to form a coalition solely with the Greens, there is political reservation between them and the Liberals. The Liberals, however, are eager to get in the Bundestag after their humiliating defeat at the last election (in the following of a coalition with Merkel's Christian Democrats in government) and may be reluctant to get directly into government again. So even if the Christian Democrats win the election it is not determined she will be the next Chancellor. The chances of Martin Schulz being elected also depend on two aspects: firstly, the winning the election with the Social Democrats. Then there are two options to form a coalition. Either they form a coalition with the Christian Democrats or with the Left Party and the Greens. Even then there are still obstacles. And that's culminate into the second aspect: the ideological barriers of the Left Party.  A Red-Red-Green Coalition not only has to come to an agreement regarding central interior policies such as security but also concerning their foreign policy. The Left Party cannot accept the foreign policy position of Social Democrats and Greens as long as they don't want to lose the credibility of their party base. Demands to leave NATO and to ease relations to Russia are unlikely to be fulfilled (at least in the radical form they propose) and would put the Left Party into identity crisis. Forming such a coalition therefore depends upon the flexibility and power interest of the Left Party and their leading figures. It's not clear if the chance to govern enable them to leave ideology behind. Thus, a coalition with the Christian Democrats could be the easiest way for Social Democrats to get Martin Schulz elected (although it is not clear to what consequences a defeat by the Social Democrats would lead in Merkel's party). Thus, I would argue from a coalition perspective it's relatively easier for Merkel to get elected than for Martin Schulz.  But what about the chance to get the most votes in the general election? It'll be a tight race. Nevertheless, I guess Merkel will win in the end but probably only with a low margin. Nowadays a lot is influenced by European and International politics and she has a high reputation and a lot of experience in these branches in Germany - even though and for some Germans because of her dealing with immigration questions. As long as Martin Schulz doesn't challenge her there and present a coherent policy and experienced personal she will still have the whiphand in the end.
People are tired of Merkel and Schulz seems like a strong candidate. On the other hand she is trusted very well by many people.

Still favor Merkel, as Schulz-bump is mostly within red-red-green coalition and will most likely decrease as Schulz becomes more known (especially his policy positions are largely unknown). CDU/CSU needs to step up their explanation of their policies, but there are no fundamental changes in the SPD functionality (which is still unfortunately rather poor)

Things are moving quickly these days.
The tricky thing in Germany is that the Chancellor is not elect by the people, but by the parliament. So if Merkel wants to stay in office, she does not only need a strong result of her own party CDU/CSU, but she needs a stable coalition with other partys in Parliament. Same for her opponent, Martin Schulz of center-left SPD.
These options seem to have a certain change according to recent polls:
CDU/CSU + SPD
SPD + CDU/CSU
CDU/CSU + Greens
SPD + Greens + Left
SPD + Greens + FDP.
CDU/CSU + Greens + FDP. A coalition of SPD and CDU/CSU, the so-called Great Coalition, will have a majority almost for sure. But it's not popular among the parties, especially the SPD doesn't like it.  SPD is dreaming of a left-wing coalition with Green and Left parties. This has been only a dream for a while, but recent polls see a chance:
http://www.wahlrecht.de/umfragen/index.htm
Looking at the polls, it's important to know that a party needs at least 5 percent to get into Parliament. So an important question is wether FDP will get in or not. If not, there might be a majority for SPD + Greens + Left. If FDP does get in, a Great Coalition might be the only option. The strongest party of a coalition names the Chancellor, so it can be both Merkel or Schulz, with Merkel a bit more likely today.

We have seen with Brexit and Trump that often polls don't accurately represent the way people will actually vote. I speculate that this is largely a product of people being counted in polls who don't end up bothering to vote.  Answering a poll takes minimal effort.  Turning up at a polling station takes much more effort.  For example, I suspect that in the recent US elections, many usual Democrat supporters chose not to vote for Candidate Clinton. Perhaps they thought it was a foregone conclusion, or perhaps they saw her as self-serving and disingenuous (my guess, ie not fact).  Similarly, in the Brexit referendum, I suspect a lot of people who may have indicated remain if polled, but didn't make it to vote because (1) they didn't feel strongly enough, or (2) were disgusted by the threats and rhetoric of those leading their preferred campaign. Being a Brit, my observation was that Brexiteers would have walked on broken glass to get to the polling station to be counted. I suspect there is a tendency for people not to bother voting when a given outcome is deemed to be near certainty. There are some people who broadly support Merkel and some who are strongly opposed.  Given what we have seen with Brexit and Trump, I suspect that those people opposed to Merkel (largely over immigration concerns) will have a very high chance of reaching the polling station.

Reiterating that I think the coalition after the election will be either:
1) CDU + AfD  (+/-FDP - not needed)
2) CDU + SDP (+/- Green +/- FDP - neither needed) 
3) SDP + Left + Green (+/- FDP) + a bit of luck  The main determinant of which coalition works I think is CDU vote share.

b) CDU 30-35% vote share (25% chance) - CDU take option 1 or 2 but in weak negotiating position - Merkel only 50/50 to keep the chancellorship
b) CDU< 30% vote share (50% chance) - SDP have the option of 2 or 3 and can probably take chancellorship from Merkel. As things stand at present, there is no plausible alternative to Merkel as yet in sight. She remains popular, and her party, the CDU, in alliance with its Bavarian partner, the CSU, is ahead in polls and is expected, at present, to be the largest party, again, in the new Bundestag. However - a lot can happen between now and the elections (scheduled for 24 September). Obviously "Europe" and "immigration" are the two big issues. The knock-on effects of Brexit - and how negotiations progress, and the manner in which they are conducted; and of a possible rise in support for nationalist/sovereignist parties at elections earlier in the year in the Netherlands and in France - may also be expected to flavour German political discourse.  The potential for Italian economic crisis - and how Germany could meaningfully respond to that.  The approach that Trump takes towards NATO may also be significant. A lot of "known unknowns" in short. Then: domestic German matters: the SPD will have a new leader, Martin Schulz, returning to Berlin from the European Parliament - a large figure strongly committed to European integration. The rise, at least in some of Germany's Lands, of the Alternativ fuer Deutschland - who mix healthy (if unusual, in the present German context) EU-scepticism, with far murkier Nazi-revivalist elements, above all in the East. The prospect (probability, even), of more Islamic terrorist attacks - either in Germany itself, or elsewhere in Europe, and their impact on public mood and debate. And the potential for dissent between the CSU and CDU (the CSU being generally more conservative) - potentially the CSU could demand a common candidate for Chancellor with a less pro-immigration policy than Merkel (for all that she has backwheeled on some of her 2015 stances).... So a combination of factors, both international and domestic, could serve, together, potentially, to undermine Merkel's standing, as, in effect, the most powerful leader in continental Europe. It is all purely potential at present, but after a year of near-revolutionary developments in the UK and US, and with the potential for France, especially, to be similarly effected (eg both of its main parties having had their anticipated presidential candidates sidelined in favour of less mainstream contenders), it would be foolish to entirely rule out something related happening, even in what on the surface remains solid, stable, well-functioning, Germany.

German voters appear in favour of her standing again. A poll carried out by the Emnid institute for the tabloid Bild am Sonntag, showed that 55% of Germans supported her standing again, while 39% opposed it.
A poll last Thursday showed that Merkel’s CDU would secure 32% of the vote if the election were held now, with the Social Democrats on around 23%, and the anti-immigrant AfD on 12% and on track to enter the Bundestag for the first time. This is a list of the major parties participating in the election
1.  Christian Democratic Union (CDU)	Christian democracy, Liberal conservatism	Angela Merkel
2.  Social Democratic Party (SPD)	Social democracy	Sigmar Gabriel
3.  The Left	Democratic socialism, Left-wing populism	Katja Kipping, Bernd Riexinger
4.  Alliance '90/The Greens	Green politics, Left-wing	Cem Özdemir, Simone Peter
5.  Christian Social Union (CSU)	Bavarian regionalism, Christian democracy	Horst Seehofer
6.  Free Democratic Party (FDP)	Liberalism, Classical liberalism	Christian Lindner
7.  	Alternative for Germany (AfD)	Right-wing populism, Euroscepticism	Frauke Petry Also for the SPD, Martin Schulz — former president of European Parliament announced his candidacy.  The political scene has traditionally been dominated by two Volksparteien, the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) and the Social Democratic Party (SPD). Each typically garnered around 40 percent of the vote and alternated in leading governments. Sunday’s poll, however, saw five parties land between 21 and 14 percent, effectively leveling the playing field between the erstwhile dominant CDU and SPD on the one hand, and the Greens, the Left, and the far-right on the other.
